column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Communicate With Older Adults
#Text=Whether you are visiting a grandparent or you are a social worker who deals with older adults from time to time , age-related health problems can present a barrier to effective communication .
#Text=Chronic conditions , such as dementia and hearing loss , as well as the effects of medication can complicate conversations and understanding .
#Text=During periods of diminished lucidity , interactions can create a frustrating and seemingly helpless experience .
#Text=However , there are techniques you can use to help facilitate interaction with older adults to create a communication-friendly environment .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Be aware of the person 's health issues .
#Text=Older adults may have health problems that add difficulty to speaking and understanding .
#Text=Be sure you consider the person 's health before you engage in communication .
#Text=For example , they may have hearing problems , speech problems , and memory loss .
#Text=These factors complicate communication .
#Text=And remember , chronological age is not always a true indicator of a person ’s health ( see Warnings ) .
#Text=Be attentive to the environment in which you are communicating .
#Text=Be sure to evaluate the environment in which you are communicating , which might have an effect on hearing and speech problems .
#Text=Is there any disturbing background noise ?
#Text=Are many people speaking in the same room ?
#Text=Is there any intrusive music ?
#Text=Are there any distractions that could affect your communication ?
#Text=Ask the older adult if the environment is comfortable for them .
#Text=If you sense any disturbance , try to move to a more peaceful and quiet location .
#Text=Speak clearly and articulately , and make eye contact .
#Text=Older adults may have trouble hearing .
#Text=It is important to articulate your words and speak clearly .
#Text=Direct your speech at the individual 's face -- not to their side .
#Text=Do not eat your words : move your mouth and pronounce each word carefully and precisely .
#Text=When your tongue “ dances ” inside your mouth when you talk , you articulate more clearly .
#Text=If your tongue “ sleeps ” and plays a passive role , you are more likely not articulating as well as you could .
#Text=Adjust your volume appropriately .
#Text=There is a difference between enunciating and talking loudly .
#Text=Learn to adapt your voice to the needs of the individual .
#Text=Evaluate the environment and how it relates to the person ’s hearing abilities .
#Text=Do n't shout simply because the listener is older .
#Text=Treat the individual with respect by articulating and speaking at a comfortable volume that is suitable for both of you .
#Text=Use clear and precise questions and sentences .
#Text=Do not hesitate to repeat or rephrase your sentences and questions if you sense there is an absence of comprehension .
#Text=Complicated questions and sentences may confuse older adults who have short-term memory or hearing loss .
#Text=Clear and precise constructions are easier to comprehend .
#Text=Use direct questions :
#Text=" Did you have soup for lunch ? "
#Text=" Did you have salad for lunch ? "
#Text=Instead of : " What did you have for lunch ? "
#Text=The more precise you are in your language , the less difficulty the elderly have in understanding .
#Text=Reduce the " noise " in your sentences and questions .
#Text=Limit your sentences and questions to 20 words or less .
#Text=Do n't use slang or filler words and phrases .
#Text=( " Like , " " well , " and " you know " are a few examples . )
#Text=Keep your sentences brief and direct to the point .
#Text=Avoid the confusion of mixed ideas and questions .
#Text=Try to define your ideas and questions logically .
#Text=If you mix ideas , it may be confusing for the older adult to understand .
#Text=Express one idea and message at a time .
#Text=For example , " It is a good idea to call John , your brother .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=A more complicated construction would be :  I think we should call your brother , John , first , and then later we could call your sister , Susan . "

column1: #Text=Employ visual aids , if possible .
#Text=If an older adult has a hearing or memory problem , it is important to be creative .
#Text=Visual aids help .
#Text=Show the individual what or who you are talking about .
#Text=For example , it may be better to say , " Is there any pain in your back ( pointing to your back ) ?

78-1	5595-5603	Warnings	abstract	new	_	_

#Text=Never act like the elderly person who you are with is ancient ( even if they are ! ) or  obsolete " .

column1: #Text=Elderly people have feelings too , and are human beings just like everyone else .
#Text=Treat them with respect and kindness .
#Text=Not all older adults have all of these problems !
#Text=There are many senior citizens who are in practically perfect mental and physical health .
#Text=Only use these steps if you sense the older adult has trouble communicating , otherwise you may offend him or her .
